memes.name: Drake Hotline Bling
memes.tone: humorous criticism; dismissive vs approving contrast
memes.semantic_description: Two-panel image of rapper Drake in a red jacket. In the top panel he turns away with a disgusted expression and raised hand, rejecting the option shown in the caption. In the bottom panel he smiles and points approvingly toward the option shown there. Used to compare two alternatives where one is rejected and the other is preferred.

memes.name: Two Buttons
memes.tone: anxious; comedic desperation about picking between bad or conflicting options
memes.semantic_description: Comic-style image of a man sweating profusely as he hesitates between pressing one of two large red buttons, each labeled with a different option in the caption. Often used to portray a person facing a difficult or impossible choice between two mutually exclusive actions or opinions.

memes.name: Distracted Boyfriend
memes.tone: playfully accusatory; comedic portrayal of temptation or disloyalty
memes.semantic_description: Stock photo where a man walking with his girlfriend turns to stare approvingly at another woman passing by, while his girlfriend looks shocked and offended. Captions usually label the man as a subject, the girlfriend as the old priority, and the passing woman as the new, more attractive distraction.

memes.name: Bernie I Am Once Again Asking For Your Support
memes.tone: wry political satire; weary persistence in asking for something again
memes.semantic_description: Photo of Bernie Sanders in a winter coat speaking to the camera on a suburban street, originally from a 2020 campaign fundraising video. Used with captions that rephrase “I am once again asking for your financial support” into repeated requests for any resource or favor.

memes.name: Running Away Balloon
memes.tone: bittersweet; reflective on how trivial things can feel huge to someone
memes.semantic_description: Panel-style image where a child chases a red balloon that has slipped away and is floating upward, while adults or other elements appear indifferent. Often labeled to contrast what feels important to one person with how insignificant it seems to others.

memes.name: Left Exit 12 Off Ramp
memes.tone: fast, impulsive, reckless but humorous
memes.semantic_description: Photo of a car on a highway making a sharp swerve to take a left exit at the last possible moment, with the overhead sign and the straight lane usually labeled in the caption. Used to depict a person or entity suddenly choosing an unexpected or irresponsible option over the reasonable default.

memes.name: UNO Draw 25 Cards
memes.tone: playful but harsh; comedic exaggeration of penalties for choices
memes.semantic_description: Meme showing a player in UNO faced with the choice to either do something (e.g., admit a truth or comply) or draw 25 cards; the joke is that the person chooses to draw 25 instead of doing the reasonable thing. Used to illustrate situations where someone would rather accept huge penalties than give in.

memes.name: Epic Handshake
memes.tone: celebratory solidarity; highlighting unexpected agreement
memes.semantic_description: Frame from the movie Predator showing two muscular arms clasped in a strong handshake. Captions typically label each arm with different groups or ideas and the handshake area with what they agree on, emphasizing a surprising point of unity.

memes.name: Disaster Girl
memes.tone: darkly mischievous; suggesting someone is satisfied by the disaster
memes.semantic_description: Photo of a young girl in the foreground smiling slyly at the camera while a house burns in the background, with firefighters responding. Used to imply that the person labeled as the girl is secretly responsible for, or pleased with, the chaos represented by the burning building.

memes.name: Gru's Plan
memes.tone: ironic; humorous breakdown of a plan that ends in embarrassment
memes.semantic_description: Four panels of Gru from Despicable Me presenting a sequence of steps on a flipchart. In the original meme, the third panel reveals a step that ruins his own plan, and in the final panel he stares awkwardly at the realization. Used to show multi-step plans that backfire, especially when the last step undermines the earlier ones.

memes.name: Always Has Been
memes.tone: deadpan; slightly dark but intellectual revelation humor
memes.semantic_description: Space illustration with two astronauts. One is looking at Earth (or another object) and says “Wait, it's all X?” in reference to some surprising truth. The other astronaut aims a gun at him and replies “Always has been.” Used to express that a supposedly new realization has always been the case.

memes.name: Sad Pablo Escobar
topics: waiting for something that never happens
memes.tone: melancholic; quiet, almost existential sadness
memes.semantic_description: Three stills of Pablo Escobar from the series Narcos sitting alone on a swing, at a table, and by a pool, looking contemplative and depressed. Used to depict lonely waiting, disappointment, or feeling abandoned.

memes.name: Anakin Padme 4 Panel
memes.tone: tragic-ironic; starts hopeful and ends in unnerving realization
memes.semantic_description: Four-panel scene from Star Wars: Attack of the Clones showing Padme smiling and asking a follow-up question, while Anakin looks serious. The common structure is: Anakin states something; Padme smiles and asks for clarification assuming a positive; the last panel reveals that the clarification is not what she hoped, often left unspoken but implied with her blank or horrified expression.

memes.name: Waiting Skeleton
memes.tone: darkly humorous; exaggeration of how long something takes
memes.semantic_description: Skeleton sitting on a bench or chair, sometimes with cobwebs, implying that the person waited until they died and decomposed. Used to exaggerate extremely long waits or delays.

memes.name: Change My Mind
memes.tone: provocative but playful; invites argument
memes.semantic_description: Conservative podcaster Steven Crowder sitting at a folding table on a campus with a sign reading something like “X is Y. Change my mind.” The sign text is replaced in memes with any strong opinion, signaling that the speaker welcomes (or pretends to welcome) challenges.

memes.name: Woman Yelling At Cat
memes.tone: highly dramatic on one side; deadpan confusion on the other
memes.semantic_description: Split meme: on the left, a crying and yelling woman being held back (from Real Housewives); on the right, a white cat sitting at a dinner table looking confused in front of a salad plate. Used to depict an intense, emotional outburst directed at someone or something that doesn't understand or care.

memes.name: Marked Safe From
memes.tone: tongue-in-cheek; trivializes or mocks drama by treating it as a disaster
memes.semantic_description: Parody of Facebook's 'Marked Safe' notification card used during disasters, with customizable text. Memes replace the disaster name with trivial or humorous events (“Marked safe from [annoying trend]”).

memes.name: Batman Slapping Robin
memes.tone: aggressively corrective; comedic violence used to snap someone out of delusion
memes.semantic_description: Comic panel where Batman slaps Robin mid-sentence. The top speech bubble usually shows Robin saying a naive or clichéd statement, and Batman’s bubble interrupts with a blunt correction. Used when forcefully rejecting a common opinion.

memes.name: X, X Everywhere
memes.tone: weary amusement; pointing out how common something has become
memes.semantic_description: Frame from Toy Story where Woody looks distressed as Buzz Lightyear gestures expansively, usually captioned as “X, X everywhere.” The X stands for some trend, problem, or object that appears to be present in overwhelming quantity.

memes.name: Buff Doge vs. Cheems
memes.tone: mocking yet playful; celebrates competence while ridiculing weakness
memes.semantic_description: Side-by-side meme of a muscular, confident Doge (buff Doge) and a small, anxious Cheems dog. Captions usually contrast something powerful, impressive, or serious on the buff side with something pathetic, silly, or downgraded on the Cheems side.

memes.name: Mocking Spongebob
memes.tone: purely mocking; childish and intentionally annoying
memes.semantic_description: Frame of SpongeBob bent over with his beak-like mouth out and eyes looking in different directions, mimicking a chicken. Often combined with alternating uppercase/lowercase text to represent someone being mocked or a statement repeated in a sarcastic tone.

memes.name: Trade Offer
memes.tone: deadpan negotiation; comedic emphasis on how unfair or absurd a deal is
memes.semantic_description: Template from a TikTok meme showing a man in a suit with two labeled columns: 'I receive:' and 'You receive:'. Used to describe trades or deals, often highlighting how one party benefits disproportionately.

memes.name: Tuxedo Winnie The Pooh
memes.tone: lightly smug; celebrating refined versions of things
memes.semantic_description: Two-panel meme of Winnie the Pooh: the first shows regular Pooh looking indifferent, while the second shows Pooh in a tuxedo, sometimes with a monocle, looking elegant. Captions contrast a basic or informal phrase with a more sophisticated or 'fancy' version.

memes.name: Success Kid
memes.tone: wholesome triumph; optimistic and celebratory
memes.semantic_description: Photo of a toddler on a beach with a clenched fist and determined expression, often paired with captions about small but meaningful successes (like narrowly avoiding a problem or gaining a small advantage).

memes.name: Y'all Got Any More Of That
memes.tone: desperately humorous; exaggerated neediness
memes.semantic_description: Image of a character based on Tyrone Biggums from Chappelle’s Show, with bugged eyes and cracked lips, wearing a beanie and scratching his neck. Commonly captioned with 'Y’all got any more of that X?' to express humorous addiction or craving for something.

memes.name: Bernie Sanders Once Again Asking
memes.tone: wearily persistent; gently self-aware plea
memes.semantic_description: Similar Bernie fundraising meme, often with the caption 'I am once again asking for your support' altered to some other repeated request—like help, attention, or resources—used to highlight how often someone has to ask.

memes.name: Expanding Brain
memes.tone: progressively more absurd; faux-intellectual
memes.semantic_description: Vertical sequence of four images showing a human brain with increasing levels of glow and cosmic imagery. Each level is labeled with a different idea, implying they become more enlightened, though often the 'highest' idea is the most nonsensical.

memes.name: One Does Not Simply
memes.tone: dramatic admonishment; warning against oversimplification
memes.semantic_description: Still from The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring with Boromir holding up his hand, originally saying “One does not simply walk into Mordor.” In memes, the phrase 'One does not simply X' introduces tasks that are much harder than people think.

memes.name: Bike Fall
memes.tone: self-own; mocking people who cause their own problems then blame others
memes.semantic_description: Simple cartoon of a cyclist riding peacefully, then sticking a stick into their own front wheel, crashing, and then blaming someone or something else in the last frame. Captions describe how the person causes their own downfall.

memes.name: I Bet He's Thinking About Other Women
memes.tone: humorous contrast; anxious speculation vs trivial reality
memes.semantic_description: Image of a couple in bed, the woman facing away looking worried with text like “I bet he’s thinking about other women,” while the man is actually thinking something trivial or absurd. Used to highlight the gap between someone’s paranoid assumption and reality.

memes.name: Ancient Aliens
memes.tone: mock-credulous; parodies wild explanations for mundane things
memes.semantic_description: Close-up of TV personality Giorgio A. Tsoukalos with wild hair and hands gesturing, usually captioned to imply 'Aliens' as the explanation. Used ironically for ridiculous or overcomplicated explanations.

memes.name: 0 days without (Lenny, Simpsons)
memes.tone: resigned; darkly comedic about recurrence of issues
memes.semantic_description: Parody of a workplace 'X days without an accident' sign, often reset back to 0. Frequently used to joke that a particular bad event happens so frequently that the counter never increases.

memes.name: Mother Ignoring Kid Drowning In A Pool
memes.tone: dark satire; criticizes how people ignore major problems to focus on minor ones
memes.semantic_description: Multi-panel meme showing a child drowning in a pool while the mother pays attention to someone else or posts online. Often labeled to show how people ignore serious problems while engaging with superficial matters.

memes.name: Megamind peeking
memes.tone: sly; subtle mischievous curiosity
memes.semantic_description: Close-up of Megamind leaning in from the side of the frame looking curious and sneaky. Used when someone is quietly watching or listening in on something that interests them.

memes.name: They're The Same Picture
memes.tone: dry; undercuts attempts to differentiate things that are alike
memes.semantic_description: Scene from The Office where corporate asks Pam to find the difference between two pictures, but she says 'They’re the same picture.' Used to claim that two supposedly different concepts, choices, or products are effectively identical.

memes.name: This Is Where I'd Put My Trophy If I Had One
memes.tone: self-deprecating; laments not having achieved something
memes.semantic_description: Screencap from The Fairly OddParents showing a character pointing to an empty shelf saying ‘This is where I’d put my trophy... if I had one.’ Used to complain humorously about lacking some reward, item, or recognition.

memes.name: Is This A Pigeon
memes.tone: gently mocking; highlights clueless misunderstandings
memes.semantic_description: Frame from the anime The Brave Fighter of Sun Fighbird where a man in glasses gestures toward a butterfly and asks, 'Is this a pigeon?' Used to represent people who completely misidentify or misunderstand obvious things.

memes.name: Monkey Puppet
memes.tone: quietly panicked; comedic discomfort
memes.semantic_description: Close-up of an orangish monkey puppet looking forward, then sideways with wide eyes and a stiff smile. Used as a reaction image when someone is caught in hypocrisy or an embarrassing situation and tries to pretend nothing is wrong.

memes.name: Oprah You Get A
memes.tone: enthusiastically generous; often used ironically
memes.semantic_description: Scene from The Oprah Winfrey Show in which Oprah stands excitedly pointing to the audience saying 'You get a car! You get a car!' In memes, the object is replaced to show something being given to everyone, often humorously negative (e.g., 'You get a bug, you all get bugs').

memes.name: Hide the Pain Harold
memes.tone: bleakly comedic; smiles through suffering
memes.semantic_description: Stock photo of an older man (nicknamed Harold) with a pained smile and distant eyes, often holding a mug or working on a laptop. Used to show someone hiding significant discomfort or sadness behind an outwardly positive demeanor.

memes.name: You Guys are Getting Paid
memes.tone: bitterly humorous; calls out unfair compensation
memes.semantic_description: Image macro of a character reacting with surprised realization, captioned 'You guys are getting paid?' Used when someone finds out others are being compensated for work they themselves have done for free.

memes.name: Squidward window
memes.tone: melancholy envy; quietly resentful
memes.semantic_description: Shot from SpongeBob SquarePants where Squidward looks out of his window while SpongeBob and Patrick are happily playing outside. Used to represent someone watching others have fun or succeed while feeling left out.

memes.name: This Is Fine
memes.tone: deadpan; darkly optimistic in the worst way
memes.semantic_description: Panel from KC Green’s webcomic 'Gunshow' showing a dog sitting calmly at a table with a mug of coffee while the room burns around him, saying 'This is fine.' Used when people act like everything is normal amid obvious crisis.

memes.name: Laughing Leo
memes.tone: smug laughter; amused superiority
memes.semantic_description: Leonardo DiCaprio in character holding a drink and laughing while pointing at something off-screen. Used as a reaction image to represent recognizing something as funny or ridiculous.

memes.name: Clown Applying Makeup
memes.tone: self-critical; highlights the process of turning oneself into a fool
memes.semantic_description: Four-panel sequence of a person gradually applying clown makeup, wig, and costume. Each step is usually labeled with a decision or belief, culminating in the final 'full clown' representing the end result of foolish reasoning.

memes.name: AJ Styles & Undertaker
memes.tone: dramatic; big-match energy
memes.semantic_description: Stills from a WWE segment featuring AJ Styles and The Undertaker facing off. Typically labeled to depict a dramatic confrontation between two forces, ideas, or people.

memes.name: Flex Tape
memes.tone: infomercial parody; exaggerates how a simple fix 'solves everything'
memes.semantic_description: Images from the Flex Tape commercial where a man slaps thick tape over a large leak or broken container, instantly stopping the water. Used to represent simplistic or superficial solutions to serious underlying problems.

memes.name: Boardroom Meeting Suggestion
memes.tone: cynically comedic; shows punishment for reason
memes.semantic_description: Four-panel comic where a boss asks for ideas in a meeting, two give on-brand suggestions, and the last person offers a sensible but unwanted idea. The boss then throws that employee out the window. Used to depict environments hostile to good suggestions.

memes.name: Pawn Stars Best I Can Do
memes.tone: dry bargaining humor; emphasizes unreasonably low offers
memes.semantic_description: Image of Rick Harrison from Pawn Stars saying something to the effect of 'Best I can do is X.' Used to parody people who severely undervalue something in negotiations.

memes.name: Absolute Cinema
memes.tone: ironic reverence; treats trivial content as high art
memes.semantic_description: Template typically using a reaction like someone deeply moved and labeling a scene, joke, or shot as 'Absolute cinema.' Used to either sincerely or ironically treat something as high-level filmmaking.

memes.name: They don't know
memes.tone: smugly introspective; quietly proud or ashamed of a secret
memes.semantic_description: Comic showing someone standing at a party thinking 'They don't know X' while everyone else is oblivious. Used when a person carries some knowledge, obsession, or issue that others around them are unaware of.

memes.name: Blank Nut Button
memes.tone: energetic; amplifies the urgency to act impulsively
memes.semantic_description: Close-up of a hand slapping a big blue 'NUT' button (often recolored or relabeled with other text). Used to show an immediate, almost reflexive response to some stimulus or desire.

memes.name: Soldier protecting sleeping child
memes.tone: heroic and sentimental
memes.semantic_description: Illustration of a soldier lying between a sleeping child and incoming threats (like projectiles or dangers) while shielding them. Used to symbolize someone taking harm or responsibility to protect someone unaware or vulnerable.

memes.name: Spider Man Triple
memes.tone: chaotic but playful; emphasizes tangled responsibility
memes.semantic_description: Meme variant featuring three Spider-Men all pointing at each other in confusion or accusation, derived from the Spider-Man pointing meme but expanded. Used when several similar parties all blame or call out each other.

memes.name: Bell Curve
memes.tone: gatekeepy or tongue-in-cheek; often mocks mid-tier understanding
memes.semantic_description: Graph-shaped template based on a bell curve, usually with low-IQ and high-IQ characters on either side agreeing on something while a 'mid' intelligent character in the middle holds a more conventional or wrong view. Used to contrast 'simple wisdom' vs overthinking.

memes.name: Types of Headaches meme
memes.tone: relatable pain; hyperbolic explanation of what 'hurts the most'
memes.semantic_description: Chart-like image showing different types of headaches (e.g., migraine, cluster) highlighted on head diagrams, with a custom fourth panel for some new comedic 'type of headache' labeled by the meme creator.

memes.name: Roll Safe Think About It
memes.tone: smug; often ironically 'smart' but actually flawed logic
memes.semantic_description: Image of a man tapping his temple and smiling knowingly. Captions articulate some 'clever' reasoning that justifies bad behavior or a loophole, often ironically pointing out that the logic is silly.

memes.name: where monkey
memes.tone: childish and fixated; comedic obsession with a specific thing
memes.semantic_description: Typical format shows a person or character looking disappointed or confused with a simple, badly phrased question like 'where monkey,' representing someone obsessively expecting a specific element that isn't present.

memes.name: All My Homies Hate
memes.tone: tribal but comedic; asserts collective hatred toward something
memes.semantic_description: Image of a group of guys with a caption 'All my homies hate X.' Commonly used to exaggerate a collective dislike within a friend group or community for some phenomenon, product, or person.

memes.name: Panik Kalm Panik
memes.tone: chaotic; depicts up-down-up emotional responses
memes.semantic_description: Three-frame meme featuring a mannequin-like head. First panel: 'Panik', second: 'Kalm', third: 'Panik' again, each with corresponding facial expressions. Used when an initial panic is briefly relieved, only to return worse.

memes.name: Whisper and Goosebumps
memes.tone: earnest or dramatic; emphasizes the impact of what's said
memes.semantic_description: Template usually showing someone whispering something into another's ear, paired with a panel of an arm or body showing goosebumps. Used to connect a line of dialogue or revelation with how emotionally intense or resonant it feels.

memes.name: Two guys on a bus
memes.tone: philosophical; juxtaposes positive and negative outlooks
memes.semantic_description: Drawing of two men on a bus: one sitting on the side facing a gloomy rock wall looking sad, the other facing a scenic view looking happy. Captions label each to show how different perspectives on the same situation change experience.

memes.name: George Bush 9/11
memes.tone: often dark or conspiratorial; politically charged
memes.semantic_description: Snapshot of George W. Bush in a classroom reading a children's book at the moment he was informed about the 9/11 attacks. Used in dark humor or critique about leadership and awareness.

memes.name: Sleeping Shaq
memes.tone: contrasting apathy and overreaction; comedic prioritization
memes.semantic_description: Two-panel meme with Shaq: first panel eyes closed, 'I sleep'; second panel glowing eyes, 'Real shit.' Used to juxtapose things that don't elicit concern vs things that suddenly command full attention.

memes.name: Friendship ended
memes.tone: overly dramatic; satirizes sudden loyalty shifts
memes.semantic_description: Photoshopped image from a viral Pakistani Facebook post: 'Friendship ended with Mudasir, now Salman is my best friend.' Used to humorously announce that someone or something has been replaced by a new favorite.

memes.name: Three-headed Dragon
memes.tone: mocking one weak member among strong ones
memes.semantic_description: Image of a three-headed dragon where two heads look fierce and the third looks derpy or goofy. Used to label three items where two are strong/serious and one is incompetent or ridiculous.

memes.name: Inhaling Seagull
memes.tone: loud and over-the-top; comedic escalation of emphasis
memes.semantic_description: Sequence of a seagull moving from normal posture to throwing its head back and screaming. Captions often show text starting normal and ending in all caps to represent shouting or intensifying emotion.

memes.name: Megamind no bitches
memes.tone: harsh mocking; calls out perceived loser status
memes.semantic_description: Close-up of Megamind with a smug but somewhat sad expression, usually paired with text 'No bitches?' and additional context. Used to roast people as being lonely or socially unsuccessful.

memes.name: A train hitting a school bus
memes.tone: dark; hyperbolic depiction of destructive interactions
memes.semantic_description: Illustration where a fast-moving train crashes into a school bus. Captions usually label train and bus as two interacting forces, with the train representing something overwhelmingly strong and the bus something fragile or unprepared.

memes.name: Grant Gustin over grave
memes.tone: petty celebratory; rejoicing over the end of something
memes.semantic_description: Photo of actor Grant Gustin (The Flash) posing and smiling next to a gravestone. Used to show someone or something celebrating or thriving after killing/replacing something else labeled on the grave.

memes.name: Trump Bill Signing
memes.tone: political; can be serious or satirical depending on captions
memes.semantic_description: Image of Donald Trump sitting at a desk holding up a signed document to the camera. The document contents are usually edited to represent whatever 'new policy' the meme creator wants to joke about.

memes.name: Anime Girl Hiding from Terminator
memes.tone: anxious; comedic mismatch between threat and hider
memes.semantic_description: Image of an anime girl hiding behind a wall while a Terminator robot stalks nearby with a weapon. Used to represent someone weak hiding from a huge and relentless threat.

memes.name: Leonardo Dicaprio Cheers
memes.tone: friendly celebratory; appreciative nod
memes.semantic_description: Scene from The Great Gatsby where Leonardo DiCaprio raises a champagne glass toward the camera with a smile. Used to toast, acknowledge, or salute something in a celebratory way.

memes.name: Grandma Finds The Internet
memes.tone: gentle ridicule; pokes fun at older people learning tech
memes.semantic_description: Stock photo of an elderly woman with glasses at a computer looking confused or concerned. Captions highlight naive misunderstandings of internet or computer concepts.

memes.name: Surprised Pikachu
memes.tone: mock-surprised; highlights how predictable outcomes still 'shock' people
memes.semantic_description: Zoomed-in image of Pikachu with a wide-eyed, open-mouthed expression of surprise. Typically used after describing someone's actions followed by an obvious consequence, then the Surprised Pikachu panel to mock their faux surprise.

memes.name: Futurama Fry
memes.tone: skeptical; mild confusion and distrust
memes.semantic_description: Frame from Futurama showing Fry squinting suspiciously. Caption typically reads 'Not sure if X or Y.' Used to express uncertainty between two interpretations of a situation.

memes.name: Scooby doo mask reveal
memes.tone: light dramatic; comedic revelation of what's 'really' behind something
memes.semantic_description: Scene from Scooby-Doo where Fred pulls off a villain's mask to reveal the person underneath. Captions label the mask as a surface explanation and the real face as the underlying cause or responsible party.

memes.name: say the line bart! simpsons
memes.tone: meta-humor; mocks how audiences demand the same lines or bits
memes.semantic_description: Scene from The Simpsons where classmates demand Bart 'say the line,' and he reluctantly says a familiar catchphrase, after which the class cheers. Used to show people pressuring someone to repeat an overused joke or phrase.

memes.name: Evil Kermit
memes.tone: tempting; comedic depiction of giving in to worst impulses
memes.semantic_description: Image of Kermit the Frog facing a hooded, evil-looking version of himself (like Emperor Palpatine). Regular Kermit expresses a reasonable thought; 'Evil Kermit' counters with a selfish, petty, or destructive alternative.

memes.name: Squid Game
memes.tone: dark and tense; often used for high-stakes metaphors
memes.semantic_description: Still from the Netflix show Squid Game, usually involving the contestants in green tracksuits or masked guards. Captions map real-world struggles to deadly children's games to emphasize harsh competition.

memes.name: Domino Effect
memes.tone: analytic and sometimes fatalistic; shows how minor actions escalate
memes.semantic_description: Image of a series of dominoes arranged from small to very large, with arrows or labels showing how a tiny initial event leads to a massive outcome as the line progresses.

memes.name: Look At Me
memes.tone: assertive; sometimes threatening in a humorous way
memes.semantic_description: Frame from Captain Phillips where the pirate says 'Look at me, I'm the captain now.' Used to represent someone taking control or demanding recognition as the one in charge.

memes.name: Third World Skeptical Kid
memes.tone: pointedly skeptical; exposes naive or privileged statements
memes.semantic_description: Photo of a young African boy giving a skeptical side-eye to a woman talking to him. Captions often highlight disbelief at unrealistic or condescending statements.

memes.name: Who Killed Hannibal
memes.tone: ironic; calls out people who cause problems then act innocent
memes.semantic_description: Scene from TV show The Eric Andre Show where Eric shoots Hannibal, then turns to the camera and asks 'Who killed Hannibal?' Used when someone causes harm and then pretends to wonder who is responsible.

memes.name: c'mon do something
memes.tone: bored frustration; gently mocking inactivity
memes.semantic_description: Simple line drawing of a stick figure poking something with a stick saying 'C’mon, do something.' Used when something (a team, market, project, etc.) feels stagnant or underperforming.

memes.name: Star Wars Yoda
memes.tone: sage and archaic; sometimes parodied as pseudo-deep
memes.semantic_description: Image of Yoda delivering a line of wisdom. Captions often mimic his unusual syntax to convey advice or mock pseudo-profound statements.

memes.name: American Chopper Argument
memes.tone: loud and emotional but comedic; dramatic back-and-forth
memes.semantic_description: Series of frames from the reality show American Chopper showing a father and son yelling at each other and throwing a chair. Each panel is captioned with parts of an argument that escalates and sometimes resolves.

memes.name: Disappointed Black Guy
memes.tone: let down; moves from excited to crushed
memes.semantic_description: Two-panel meme: first shows a black man smiling excitedly at something, second shows him immediately afterward with a displeased, disappointed face when reality differs from what he expected.

memes.name: No - Yes
memes.tone: reluctantly positive; shows progression from opposition to acceptance
memes.semantic_description: Simple two-panel format where the top shows 'No.' and the bottom shows 'Yes.' with the same character, often to depict someone initially refusing something and then later accepting it.

memes.name: Finding Neverland
memes.tone: empathetic; softens harsh realities with whimsical framing
memes.semantic_description: Scene from the film Finding Neverland: adult character sitting with a boy, often with the adult speaking a sober line and the child reacting. Used to frame gentle but sobering explanations in a sentimental context.

memes.name: Grim Reaper Knocking Door
memes.tone: dark; grim but playful visualization of death visiting targets
memes.semantic_description: Comic-style image of the Grim Reaper going door to door, leaving a trail of blood behind. Each door is usually labeled to show successive targets being 'claimed', implying something systematically eliminating items in a category.

memes.name: The Rock Driving
memes.tone: comic surprise; driver is caught off guard by passenger response
memes.semantic_description: Two-panel still from a movie scene where Dwayne 'The Rock' Johnson is driving a car; in the first panel he asks a question while looking forward, and in the second he looks back in shock at an unexpected answer from the passenger.

memes.name: is this butterfly
memes.tone: gently mocking; emphasizes ignorance of basic distinctions
memes.semantic_description: Variant of the 'Is This a Pigeon?' anime meme where the character points at something mislabeled as a butterfly/pigeon. The item is usually something obviously not fitting the category used in the caption.

memes.name: Two Paths
memes.tone: contemplative or comedic; frames choices starkly
memes.semantic_description: Simple drawing of a road that splits into two paths, often with each path labeled differently. A person or arrow may be shown choosing one. Used to represent binary choices between approaches or lifestyles.

memes.name: spiderman pointing at spiderman
memes.tone: humorous confrontation; points out that two sides are the same
memes.semantic_description: Classic Spider-Man cartoon frame with two Spider-Men pointing at each other in confusion. Used when two people or groups are functionally identical or guilty of the same behavior while accusing each other.

memes.name: whe i'm in a competition and my opponent is
memes.tone: self-deprecating anxiety; comedic fear in competitive settings
memes.semantic_description: Meme format showing an individual reacting fearfully or nervously upon realizing their opponent is far more skilled, prepared, or intense than expected. Often used with gaming or sports context.

memes.name: Doakes
memes.tone: intense; confrontational satisfaction at being right
memes.semantic_description: Detective Doakes from Dexter, often captioned with lines suggesting he always suspected something ('Surprise, motherf***er'). Used when someone finally confronts or confirms a suspicion about another.

memes.name: The Scroll Of Truth
topics: truth people don't want to accept
memes.tone: didactic yet comedic; forces a truth on someone who prefers denial
memes.semantic_description: Cartoon of a character discovering an ancient scroll labeled with a truth, reading it, and then angrily discarding it. Used to show how people react when confronted with an uncomfortable but accurate statement.

memes.name: Gus Fring we are not the same
memes.tone: sternly elitist; emphasizes being on a higher level
memes.semantic_description: Gus Fring from Breaking Bad in a serious pose, often captioned 'We are not the same, I X.' Used to contrast one’s strict standards or discipline with someone else’s perceived laxness.

memes.name: Charlie Conspiracy (Always Sunny in Philidelphia)
memes.tone: frantic and unhinged; comedic paranoia
memes.semantic_description: Scene from It’s Always Sunny in Philadelphia showing Charlie in front of a corkboard covered with papers and string, gesturing wildly. Used to depict someone presenting an overly complicated, conspiracy-like explanation or pattern.
